name: OSCAR 7 (AO-7)
description: Launched in 1974, this vintage satellite continues to operate reliably, bridging generations of amateur radio enthusiasts. Its enduring presence in orbit is a testament to timeless engineering and community spirit.

name: PHASE 3B (AO-10)
description: Launched in 1983, this pioneering satellite expanded the horizons of amateur radio with its high elliptical orbit. AO-10 set the stage for long-distance communication and inspired a new era of space-based experimentation.

name: UOSAT 2 (UO-11)
description: Launched in 1984, this educational satellite brought space science to classrooms worldwide with its data transmissions. UO-11 marked a turning point in making satellite technology accessible for learning and research.

name: LUSAT (LO-19)
description: Launched in 1990, this Argentine-built satellite showcased international collaboration in amateur space projects. LO-19 continues to symbolize innovation and dedication within the global ham radio community.

name: EYESAT A (AO-27)
description: Launched in 1993, this compact satellite has provided reliable FM voice repeater services to operators worldwide. AO-27's accessibility made it a favorite for newcomers to satellite communication, opening the door for countless enthusiasts to experience their first space-based QSO.

name: ITAMSAT (IO-26)
description: Launched in 1993, this Italian gem brought European innovation to orbit with its sophisticated packet radio capabilities. IO-26 embodied the spirit of international collaboration, connecting operators across borders while showcasing Italy's growing presence in the amateur satellite community.

name: RADIO ROSTO (RS-15)
description: Launched in 1994, this Russian workhorse opened new communication pathways with its unique orbital characteristics. RS-15's stable platform and reliable transponder have connected operators across vast distances, bridging East and West through the universal language of amateur radio.

name: JAS-2 (FO-29)
description: Launched in 1996, this Japanese marvel has outlived expectations with its exceptional longevity and signal clarity. FO-29's linear transponder continues to deliver pristine communication capabilities, earning it a special place in the hearts of serious satellite operators around the world.

name: TECHSAT 1B (GO-32)
description: Launched in 1998, this Israeli technological trailblazer combined cutting-edge research with amateur radio accessibility. GO-32 demonstrated how academic innovation could serve both scientific and community purposes, creating a bridge between professional aerospace development and grassroots radio enthusiasts.

name: ISS (ZARYA)
description: Launched in 1998, this orbital outpost represents humanity's most ambitious space endeavor while remaining accessible to amateur radio enthusiasts. The ISS's amateur radio station has connected astronauts with earthbound operators and students worldwide, bringing the wonder of space directly into homes and classrooms across the planet.

name: PCSAT (NO-44)
description: Launched in 2001, this innovative satellite revolutionized position reporting with its APRS capabilities in orbit. NO-44 brought Internet-connected tracking to the amateur satellite world, enabling a whole new class of applications and inspiring countless experiments in automated data exchange across the globe.

name: SAUDISAT 1C (SO-50)
description: Launched in 2002, this Saudi Arabian contribution to amateur space quickly became a favorite for its reliable FM repeater operation. SO-50's predictable passes and strong downlink signal have made it the perfect entry point for thousands of operators getting their first taste of satellite communication.

name: CUTE-1 (CO-55)
description: Launched in 2003, this adorably named Japanese CubeSat pioneered the miniaturization of amateur satellite technology. CO-55 demonstrated that palm-sized satellites could perform serious communication tasks, setting the stage for an explosion of university-built amateur satellites and democratizing access to space.

name: CUBESAT XI-IV (CO-57)
description: Launched in 2003, this University of Tokyo creation has defied all longevity expectations with its remarkable durability in the harsh space environment. CO-57's incredible operational lifespan has provided invaluable data on CubeSat design while continuing to transmit its cheerful signals to an appreciative worldwide audience.

name: MOZHAYETS 4 (RS-22)
description: Launched in 2003, this Russian student-built satellite combined educational objectives with genuine amateur radio capability. RS-22 showcased the importance of hands-on satellite engineering experience, inspiring a generation of young Russian technologists while providing communication opportunities to operators worldwide.

name: CUBESAT XI-V
description: Launched in 2005, this enhanced follow-up to the successful XI-IV demonstrated the rapid evolution of Japanese CubeSat technology. XI-V's improved camera and communication systems proved that iterative design in small satellites could yield significant advancements, all while maintaining an open connection to the amateur radio community.

name: CUTE-1.7+APD II (CO-65)
description: Launched in 2008, this technologically advanced Japanese CubeSat pushed the boundaries of miniaturized space technology with its avalanche photodiode experiments. CO-65's sophisticated systems in such a tiny package demonstrated the impressive capabilities that could be packed into the CubeSat format, inspiring a new wave of ambitious amateur satellite designs.

name: SEEDS II (CO-66)
description: Launched in 2008, this plucky Japanese CubeSat focused on growing the space workforce through hands-on student development. CO-66 transformed theoretical classroom knowledge into practical space engineering experience, all while transmitting voice messages and images that connected students directly with the ham radio community.

name: YUBILEINY (RS-30)
description: Launched in 2008, this commemorative Russian satellite celebrated Sputnik's 50th anniversary with flair by broadcasting audio recordings replicating the historic first satellite's beeps. RS-30's symbolic mission reconnected modern operators with the dawn of the space age, while its educational outreach ignited curiosity about satellite communication in a new generation.

name: KKS-1 (KISEKI)
description: Launched in 2009, this Japanese satellite's name appropriately means 'miracle' – reflecting the wonder of student-built spacecraft reaching orbit. KISEKI combined educational objectives with genuine amateur radio capabilities, transmitting voice recordings and telemetry that connected Tokyo University students directly with the global amateur community.

name: SWISSCUBE
description: Launched in 2009, this Swiss precision spacecraft brought Alpine engineering excellence to orbit with its sophisticated airglow measurement mission. SWISSCUBE's blend of scientific objectives with amateur radio accessibility demonstrated how educational satellites could simultaneously serve research purposes while keeping open channels to the ham community.

name: BEESAT-1
description: Launched in 2009, this busy German picosatellite lives up to its bee-inspired name with constant activity testing miniaturized reaction wheels. BEESAT-1 pushed the boundaries of what could fit in a single-unit CubeSat, demonstrating sophisticated attitude control systems while maintaining amateur radio communication channels for global operator engagement.

name: ITUPSAT1
description: Launched in 2009, this pioneering Turkish satellite marked the country's serious entry into amateur space activities. ITUPSAT1 combined passive magnetic stabilization with amateur communication capabilities, demonstrating how emerging space nations could develop meaningful aerospace programs that engaged both students and the international radio community.

name: XIWANG-1 (HOPE-1)
description: Launched in 2009, this Chinese satellite lived up to its hopeful name by demonstrating the country's growing capabilities in amateur space communication. XIWANG-1 combined APRS packet radio with voice messaging systems, opening new channels between Chinese operators and the international community while showcasing the country's technological advancement.

name: O/OREOS (USA 219)
description: Launched in 2010, this NASA nanosatellite combined cutting-edge astrobiology experiments with amateur radio accessibility. O/OREOS investigated how living organisms and organic compounds behave in space while maintaining open communication channels, demonstrating how even sophisticated science missions could include amateur radio components for broader community engagement.

name: JUGNU
description: Launched in 2011, this sparkling Indian nanosatellite (named after a firefly) illuminated the country's growing space capabilities. JUGNU combined micro-imaging systems with amateur radio transmissions, showcasing IIT Kanpur's engineering prowess while establishing India's presence in the educational CubeSat community.

name: SRMSAT
description: Launched in 2011, this student-built Indian nanosatellite expanded the country's educational space portfolio with impressive capabilities. SRMSAT's greenhouse gas monitoring instruments demonstrated that serious environmental science could be conducted from a tiny platform, all while maintaining amateur radio downlinks that engaged operators worldwide.

name: STRAND-1
description: Launched in 2013, this innovative British satellite boldly took everyday technology to orbit by incorporating a Google Nexus smartphone as a payload. STRAND-1's creative approach to space engineering demonstrated how commercial off-the-shelf components could be adapted for space use, all while transmitting amateur radio signals accessible to hobbyists with modest equipment.

name: ZACUBE-1 (TSHEPISOSAT)
description: Launched in 2013, this pioneering South African CubeSat marked the nation's entry into the space age with style. ZACUBE-1's combination of space weather instruments with amateur radio communication capabilities demonstrated how smaller nations could develop meaningful space programs that contributed both scientifically and to the global amateur community.

name: GOMX-1
description: Launched in 2013, this Danish technological demonstrator showcased innovative approaches to aircraft tracking from space. GOMX-1's pioneering ADS-B receiver proved that satellites could monitor air traffic globally, all while maintaining amateur radio downlinks that allowed enthusiasts to participate in this revolutionary aviation safety advancement.

name: CUBEBUG-2 (LO-74)
description: Launched in 2013, this Argentinian satellite (affectionately nicknamed 'Manolito') brought Latin American innovation to orbit with style. LO-74's open-source approach to satellite design and operation created unprecedented transparency in space engineering, inviting global participation while establishing Argentina as a significant player in amateur space communication.

name: FUNCUBE-1 (AO-73)
description: Launched in 2013, this educational British satellite was specifically designed to captivate students' imagination through hands-on space engagement. AO-73's dual-purpose mission combined classroom-friendly telemetry with transponder capabilities for radio amateurs, creating a bridge between educational inspiration and hobby operation that has enchanted both students and operators worldwide.

name: UWE-3
description: Launched in 2013, this German technological marvel packed sophisticated attitude determination and control systems into a tiny package. UWE-3's precise orientation capabilities demonstrated precision engineering at the picosatellite scale, while its amateur radio transmissions invited operators worldwide to monitor these impressive technological demonstrations in real-time.

name: UNISAT-6
description: Launched in 2014, this versatile Italian platform demonstrated a new model of satellite deployment by carrying and releasing multiple smaller CubeSats. UNISAT-6's mothership role showcased the growing sophistication of university-built spacecraft, while its amateur radio capabilities ensured that the broader community could follow these technological innovations from their home stations.

name: DUCHIFAT-1
description: Launched in 2014, this Israeli educational satellite was entirely built by high school students – proving that aerospace engineering isn't just for college-level studies. DUCHIFAT-1's successful deployment and operation shattered age barriers in satellite development, inspiring younger students worldwide while providing reliable packet radio services to the amateur community.

name: QB50P1
description: Launched in 2014, this precursor to an ambitious international constellation demonstrated the potential of coordinated CubeSat networks. QB50P1's successful operation paved the way for dozens of follow-on satellites studying the lower thermosphere, while its amateur radio component ensured public engagement with this groundbreaking scientific collaboration across multiple countries.

name: LILACSAT-2
description: Launched in 2015, this Chinese student satellite delighted operators worldwide with its innovative FM transponder and voice messaging capabilities. LILACSAT-2's surprisingly powerful transmissions and user-friendly features made it an instant favorite in the amateur community, showcasing China's growing contribution to accessible space communication technology.

name: FOX-1A (AO-85)
description: Launched in 2015, this American Radio Relay League satellite brought next-generation FM transponder technology to amateurs worldwide. AO-85's accessible voice repeater capabilities reinvigorated interest in satellite communication among entry-level operators, providing an ideal stepping stone into space operations while carrying radiation experiments that benefited the scientific community.

name: CAS-2T & KS-1Q
description: Launched in 2016, this Chinese amateur satellite duo demonstrated creative engineering by connecting a technology demonstrator with an educational platform. The paired spacecraft showcased innovative approaches to orbital collaboration, providing voice repeater and APRS capabilities that have been enthusiastically embraced by operators throughout Asia and beyond.

name: ZHUHAI-1 02 (CAS-4B)
description: Launched in 2017, this Chinese commercial/amateur hybrid satellite demonstrated how professional space assets could incorporate amateur radio capabilities. CAS-4B's powerful linear transponder and APRS digipeater highlighted China's growing sophistication in satellite communication, offering exceptional quality signals that have earned admiration from amateur operators worldwide.

name: ZHUHAI-1 01 (CAS-4A)
description: Launched in 2017 alongside its twin CAS-4B, this Chinese satellite combined Earth observation capabilities with amateur radio services. CAS-4A's incorporation of ham radio transponders into a commercial remote sensing platform demonstrated China's commitment to serving the amateur community even as it developed advanced space capabilities for economic and scientific purposes.

name: RADFXSAT (FOX-1B)
description: Launched in 2017, this American radiation-research satellite combined serious science with amateur radio accessibility. FOX-1B's study of radiation effects on advanced computing systems provided valuable data for spacecraft designers, while its FM transponder created opportunities for operators worldwide to participate in cutting-edge aerospace research through their hobby activities.

name: DIWATA-2B
description: Launched in 2018, this Philippine microsatellite symbolized the nation's growing space capabilities with its advanced Earth observation instruments. DIWATA-2B's amateur radio component created a bridge between professional remote sensing and hobby communication, showcasing how smaller nations could develop meaningful space programs while engaging with the international amateur community.

name: ES'HAIL 2
description: Launched in 2018, this groundbreaking Qatari satellite revolutionized amateur radio by hosting the first geostationary transponders dedicated to ham use. ES'HAIL 2's powerful and stable signals cover a third of the globe, enabling unprecedented communication quality that has transformed what amateurs can achieve, while bringing together operators from Europe, Africa, and Asia in a shared communications platform.

name: FOX-1CLIFF (AO-95)
description: Launched in 2018, this American CubeSat continued the successful Fox series with enhanced capabilities and experimental payloads. AO-95's combination of radiation research with accessible FM communication demonstrated the ongoing evolution of amateur satellite design, providing valuable scientific data while offering user-friendly voice operation that welcomed newcomers to satellite operation.

name: ITASAT
description: Launched in 2018, this Brazilian university satellite showcased South American aerospace engineering with impressive capabilities. ITASAT's combination of environmental data collection with amateur radio digipeater functions highlighted Brazil's growing space presence, providing valuable data links for remote scientific stations while offering communication opportunities to operators throughout the Americas.

name: JY1SAT (JO-97)
description: Launched in 2018, this Jordanian satellite commemorated the late King Hussein (amateur callsign JY1) with a fitting tribute to his passion for radio. JO-97's FUNcube-style design created educational opportunities for Middle Eastern students while its transponder united the amateur community in celebration of a monarch who used ham radio to connect with people around the world regardless of political boundaries.

name: UWE-4
description: Launched in 2018, this German technological demonstrator showcased revolutionary electric propulsion systems miniaturized for CubeSat platforms. UWE-4's experimental NanoFEEP thrusters represented a breakthrough in small satellite maneuverability, while its amateur radio transmissions invited the ham community to follow these pioneering tests that are reshaping what tiny spacecraft can accomplish in orbit.

name: DUCHIFAT-3
description: Launched in 2019, this Israeli student satellite continued the successful DUCHIFAT series with enhanced Earth observation capabilities. DUCHIFAT-3's focus on wildfire detection showcased how educational spacecraft could address serious environmental challenges, while its amateur radio component ensured that young satellite builders maintained connection with the broader community of space enthusiasts.

name: TIANYAN 01
description: Launched in 2019, this Chinese amateur astronomy satellite opened the wonders of space observation to radio enthusiasts worldwide. TIANYAN 01's innovative combination of optical sensors with amateur communication systems created unprecedented opportunities for hobbyists to participate in celestial studies, bridging astronomy and radio communities in a shared exploration of the cosmos.

name: RS-44 & BREEZE-KM R/B
description: Launched in 2019, this Russian amateur radio payload impressively repurposed a rocket upper stage as a long-term orbital platform. RS-44's creative use of existing space hardware demonstrated resourceful engineering, transforming what would have been space debris into a powerful linear transponder that delights operators with its exceptional signal quality and unique technical characteristics.

name: SALSAT
description: Launched in 2020, this German experimental satellite introduced innovative spectrum monitoring capabilities to orbit. SALSAT's sophisticated software-defined radio payload could analyze signal environments across wide frequency ranges, providing valuable data on radio spectrum usage while transmitting these findings to amateur operators, creating a collaborative approach to understanding our increasingly crowded electromagnetic environment.

name: LEDSAT
description: Launched in 2021, this Italian CubeSat literally shined with its innovative LED-based optical tracking system. LEDSAT's powerful light beacons enabled ground-based tracking with simple equipment, democratizing satellite observation while its radio transmissions provided technical data that helped correlate optical and radio tracking methods in an elegant demonstration of multi-modal space communication.

name: XW-3 (CAS-9)
description: Launched in 2021, this Chinese amateur satellite represented a new generation of capabilities with its advanced multi-mode transponder system. CAS-9's combination of linear and digital transponders showcased the evolution of amateur space communication, providing both traditional voice operations and next-generation digital modes that are preparing the community for future communications innovations.

name: STRATOSAT-TK 1 (RS52S)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian student satellite combined atmospheric research with amateur radio education in an elegant package. RS52S's environmental sensors collect valuable data on stratospheric conditions while transmitting findings through amateur frequencies, creating a dual-purpose mission that serves both scientific advancement and community engagement in space exploration.

name: UMKA 1 (RS40S)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian technology demonstrator (whose name references a beloved cartoon polar bear) brought playful innovation to serious space testing. RS40S's experimental systems explore new approaches to satellite communication and control while its amateur radio component invites enthusiasts to participate in these cutting-edge tests, blending technical advancement with community engagement.

name: CUBESX-HSE 3 (RS42S)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian university satellite demonstrated how higher education institutions could develop meaningful space capabilities. RS42S's combination of educational objectives with amateur radio accessibility created opportunities for students to gain hands-on aerospace experience while connecting with the broader community of space enthusiasts through open communication channels.

name: MONITOR-3 (RS58S)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian Earth observation CubeSat creatively combined environmental monitoring with amateur radio capabilities. RS58S's compact sensors collect valuable data on our changing planet while its accessible transmissions ensure public engagement with these findings, demonstrating how even small satellites can contribute to both scientific understanding and community education.

name: MONITOR-4 (RS57S)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian environmental satellite continued the successful MONITOR series with enhanced sensing capabilities. RS57S's focus on atmospheric composition monitoring provided important data for climate research, while its amateur radio component ensured that scientific findings remained accessible to the public, creating a bridge between professional research and community engagement.

name: MONITOR-2 (RS39S)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian Earth observation platform expanded the growing constellation of environmental monitoring CubeSats. RS39S's specialized sensors focus on specific atmospheric parameters important for climate modeling, while its amateur radio transmissions invite public participation in environmental science, democratizing access to important ecological data.

name: SVYATOBOR 1 (RS60S)
description: Launched in 2023, this uniquely named Russian satellite (referencing a mythological forest protector) focused on environmental monitoring with poetic purpose. RS60S's combination of woodland observation capabilities with amateur radio outreach created a powerful tool for tracking forest health and fire risks, connecting nature conservation efforts with the technical capabilities of the amateur satellite community.

name: VIZARD-METEO (RS38S)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian environmental satellite combined advanced meteorological sensors with amateur radio outreach. RS38S's focus on weather pattern analysis provided valuable data for climate research, while its accessible transmissions ensured public engagement with these findings, creating a bridge between professional research and community education.

name: NANOZOND 1 (RS49S)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian nanosatellite focused on innovative approaches to Earth observation and amateur radio communication. RS49S's compact design and advanced sensors demonstrated the potential of small satellites to contribute to environmental monitoring, while its accessible transmissions invited public participation in these important scientific endeavors.

name: POLYTECH-UNIVERSE 3 (R*)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian university satellite showcased the growing capabilities of academic institutions in space exploration. R*'s combination of educational objectives with amateur radio accessibility created opportunities for students to gain hands-on aerospace experience while connecting with the broader community of space enthusiasts through open communication channels.

name: UTMN 2 (RS27S)
description: Launched in 2023, this Russian university satellite focused on innovative approaches to Earth observation and amateur radio communication. RS27S's compact design and advanced sensors demonstrated the potential of small satellites to contribute to environmental monitoring, while its accessible transmissions invited public participation in these important scientific endeavors.

description: Launched in 2023, this Russian nanosatellite focused on innovative approaches to Earth observation and amateur radio communication.
